job_title: Adjunct Professor in Lake Mary, FL
pros: Flexible schedule and autonomy with classes
cons: Raises few and far between. While hourly rate sounds impressive it is only for the time spent in the classroom and not for all the other associated and required time spent working, a minimum of 5-7 days a week. Don't expect to work hard and be promoted to full time, despite possibly teaching more classes than full time professors. The school works hard to keep full time salaried professors to a minimum and relies heavily on part time adjunct instructors.

pros: Flexible hours, works well when going to college, responsive and understanding leadership.
cons: In general, for part time you will only get max 29 hours.

review_title: They do not appreciate their employees
pros: Many of your coworkers are Great, hard-working people. Benefits are mostly good. State retirement system is great.
cons:
Salaries are very low. When a comp study was done 4/5 (?) Years ago, they acknowledged that MANY of our positions' salaries were way below the midrange. The administration only decided to bring them up to 85% of the Midrange. This was based on year old data - and that bump up was only implemented After an annual 3% raise was given. So if the raise didn't bring someone up to 85% of the Prior Year's midrange, only then was that person's salary increased. So those positions missed out on their raises that year. There have been multiple years since when no raises were given while other colleges' staff Were given raises, so SSC lags even farther behind.

In addition, staffing levels are very low in many areas- specifically Advising and Counseling, and Financial Aid. Some professional staff regularly easily work 50-60 hours/week with no additional compensation or even appreciation which was most recently evident when some of those same staff, with excellent annual evaluations, had their contracts not renewed - simply for verbalizing the truth when asked why issues happen - due to upper administration not giving the proper support to the areas that need it. This College also does not pay enough to attract the required technical expertise to make things run smoothly. The Financial Aid office is a prime example of this.

pros: Very understanding of your schedule, simple work with fun coworkers

pros: Great coworkers, Free Training, Freedom to plan classes
cons: Head of department is on your side, but deans are not. Students are always right even if they complain unreasonably. The salary I summited is for 1 class.

pros: Some employees makes it fun
cons: Management needs to be revamped

pros: Benefits, 2 weeks for winter, spring break, and 9 other holidays paid , plus a minimum of 20 PTO, health insurance is awesome, FRS retirement. They consistently give raises.
cons: Executives are out of touch. Salaries  for the majority of employees are well below average even when considering the great employee benefits the college offers. Budgets are limited due to management who have higher than normal salaries they do not deserve. College president's salary is outrageous. While it is a diverse work place it is mostly Gen-X and Baby boomers who are stuck in their old ways and not always  open to innovative ideas. Management is pressured to give lower employee reviews to reduce the amount of increase on budgets due to salary increases. It is difficult to move within departments at the college. It is a who you know kind of place---the culture does support developing and keeping talented young professionals. HR is clearly there to just protect the college. Also be warned that positions that should be considered professional status are labeled career service to justify the lower than average salary. This place is old school and the red tape is just something you'll have to accept working here. Negotiating salary is done with HR, and they are selective on which positions they will actually negotiate a salary on.

review_title: Love the employees, beware of management
pros: It is a growth industry, the college has positioned itself to attract more customers, the instructors are fabulous and the professional staff are always ready to help the students
cons:
the Executive staff is largely incompetent and practices the crisis model of management. When there is an actual crisis, no-one pays attention.

Often times, middle level management are allowed to run their departments like small fiefdoms rather than part of an integrated whole with little respect for college policy

pros: Very flexible schedule, great work environment, several growth opportunities, great networking opportunities, job might include helping to set up fun events at the college.
cons: There really aren't a lot of downsides to working here. The only downsides are low pay and that you might not get a lot of hours if your department has a really tight budget to pay employees with.

review_title: My experience working at SSC was bitter/sweet, and mostly frustrating.
pros: Very good benefits, great opportunity and incentives for professional enrichment and continuing education.
cons: Very "click-ish," especially within the administration. Administrative decisions regarding faculty are often made using devices such as favoritism, or intimidation. They see nothing wrong with using the faculty and throwing them away when they're finished with them. There seems to be a lot of drama, backstabbing, and setting up people to fail. Tenure is often granted on the person being liked by the supervisor instead of the person being a candidacy of merit before a tenure review board.

review_title: Great place to work but not in my department Records office
